Developing National Consultants in  
Developing Member Countries  
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations Group 2 
Principal Director  P. Daltrop, Central Operations Services Office (COSO) 
Directors   R. Marshall, Central Operations Services Division 1, COSO 
R. Robertson, Central Operations Services Division 2, COSO 
   
Team leader  T. Woods, Procurement Specialist, COSO

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The policy paper on the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Use of Consultants1 and the 
revised ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants2 support and strengthen ADB’s ongoing 
commitment to promote the use of developing member country (DMC) national consultants. In 
the past, this support has included (i) in-country "developing domestic consultants" (DDC) 
seminars focused on raising awareness of and providing advice on how to win ADB business, 
and (ii) in some countries, strategic studies of the consulting industry.3 This regional technical 
assistance (RETA)4 supports improving and expanding DDC seminars (now called "developing 
national consultants" [DNC] seminars) in selected DMCs over a 2-year period (late 2006 to 
2008), including the creation of web-based training materials to reach national consultants who 
do not physically attend the seminars. 
  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB's demand for national consulting services has grown dramatically over the past 10 
years. According to an analysis of ADB technical assistance (TA) projects, on average, national 
consultants, in DMCs accounted for 40% of consultant person-months in 2005, up from 30% in 
1995. An analysis of 65 randomly selected ADB loan projects from 2000 to 2005 indicated that 
on average 1,000 national consulting months were required per project. This growth has been 
fuelled by a couple of factors, including the improved quality of national consultants in some 
countries, and by the perception that national consulting inputs are less expensive and often 
more sustainable than international consultants. Demand for national consultants has also been 
stimulated by DMC governments’ requirements to reorganize, downsize and outsource more 
DMC government activities to consultants. However, within the Asia–Pacific region, there are 
significant disparities in the ability of countries to meet the growing demand for international-
quality national consulting services. 
 
3.  National  consulting  industries  in  Asia  are  at  various  stages  of  growth.  Developed 
economies,  including  Japan,  Republic  of  Korea,  Malaysia,  and  Singapore,  have  mature 
consulting industries and export their services to other countries in the region and beyond. Of 
the middle-income countries, India has a developed national industry and likewise exports 
services  within  the  region;  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  has  strong  capabilities  in  the 
engineering sector, is rapidly building consulting capacity in the “softer” sectors, and has been 
exporting services under its own bilateral aid program. DMCs with stronger English language 
capabilities, such as Bangladesh, Pakistan, the Philippines, and Sri Lanka, possess growing 
national industries and have had some success in exporting consulting services within the 
region. Other countries are lagging for various reasons, including the absence of a regulated 
business environment, lack of awareness of the benefits of consulting, a weak consulting skills 
base, and the absence of strong associations to represent and promote the national consulting

2   
industry. These deficiencies can result in serious imbalances between the demand for and the 
supply  of  quality  national  consultants—both  firms  and  individuals.  Such  imbalances  create 
incentives to broaden the capacity of the national consulting industry throughout the region. 
 
4.  The DDC seminars have resulted in tangible gains to the national consulting industries of 
many DMCs. In general, the DMCs and the sponsors of these seminars—usually consulting 
associations—have been enthusiastic about the seminars. However, the content and delivery 
approaches of these seminars were insufficiently tailored to individual DMCs. The seminars 
featured  a  standardized  agenda  that  focused  primarily  on  ADB’s  recruitment  policies  and 
procedures for selection and engagement of consultants. Selection of participants was often 
limited to members of the sponsoring association. Government officers were rarely invited, and 
participation by consulting entities other than consulting firms and individual consultants—
including nongovernment organizations (NGOs) or universities—was limited. As a result, the 
seminars failed to take advantage of the opportunity to increase demand for consultants by 
demonstrating the benefits of consulting to the public and private sectors. The seminars also 
failed to stimulate the supply side by creating awareness of the business and employment 
opportunities that a robust consulting industry can offer. 
 
5.  The  planning,  scheduling,  content,  and  delivery  approaches  of  the  2006–2008 
seminars—renamed  DNC  seminars—will  be  restructured  to  reflect  the  above  issues  and 
shortcomings through: 
 
(i)  preparing a suite of training modules,5 including new options for (a) enhancing a 
national consulting industry, (b) the consulting firm’s business development cycle, 
and (c) fraud and corruption in the recruitment process; 
(ii)  prioritizing the scheduling of the seminars through closer consultation with ADB 
regional departments and resident missions, and taking into account specific 
requests from DMCs and country strategy programs; 
(iii)  tailoring, in consultation with the sponsor, the seminar modules to meet the 
unique requirements of each DMC (Appendix 2); 
(iv)  encouraging  the  seminar  sponsors  to  broaden  participation  by  inviting  key 
industry players including (a) government officials who are involved in regulatory 
and procurement reform; (b) representatives from (other) consulting associations; 
(c) consulting firms; (d) individual consultants; and (e) other entities, including 
NGOs, research institutes, and universities; 
(v)  enhancing  approaches  to  seminar  delivery  through  the  incorporation  of 
interactive exercises, case studies, and  greater use of laptops; and 
(vi)  designing  and  disseminating  an  interactive  digital  versatile  disc  (DVD)  for 
electronic outreach of the DNC seminars. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The design and monitoring framework is included as Appendix 1. The impact of the TA 
will be the establishment of international-standard consulting industries in DMCs. The outcome 
will be strengthened DMC consulting industries, evidenced by (i) increased number of national 
firms and individuals registering, submitting expressions of interest in, and winning ADB TA and 
                                                 
5  ADB’s Central Operations Services Office (COSO) is currently reviewing the content, modularization, and delivery 
of its outreach seminars, including seminars on country project implementation and administration, business 
opportunities, use of consultants, results-focused project performance management systems, and developing 
national consultants.

3
loan consulting assignments; (ii) increased use of national consultants in DMC government-
financed projects, (iii) a broader range of service providers in the DMCs; and (iv) an increased 
number of national consultants winning regional assignments. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  ADB’s Central Operations Services Office (COSO) has outlined a framework for baseline 
rating and monitoring emergence of DMCs' consulting industries (Appendix 2). These range 
from  “undeveloped”  (characterized  by  an  unregulated  procurement  environment,  few 
independent consulting firms, narrow demand, and a limited supply base) to “mature” (with a 
broad  range  of  service  providers,  regulated  procurement  environments,  public  and  private 
sectors actively using consultants, and services exported regionally and globally). COSO will 
use this framework to tailor the content of the DNC seminars and relay focused advice to DMCs 
based on the status of their national consulting industries. By way of example, a DNC seminar 
in a country with an “undeveloped” national consulting industry might include a special module 
on how to write curriculums vitae, in contrast to a seminar in a country with a “developed” 
industry, which might include a module on diagnostic analysis of the national consulting industry. 
 
8.  Planning and scheduling of DNC seminars for a given year will commence in September 
of the preceding year, and will be prioritized through (i) consultation with regional departments 
and resident missions in relation to current, anticipated, potential TA and loan portfolios; and 
(ii) direct requests from DMCs. Sponsors will be identified, and based on the industry status and 
the specific demands of the sponsor, the seminars will deliver modules that reflect the needs of 
the DMC's consulting industry. COSO will encourage the sponsor to advertise the seminar 
locally as well as on the ADB website at least 2 months in advance, and select a broad range of 
participant representatives of the consulting industry, including government staff responsible for 
procurement,  and  service  providers  including  firms,  individuals,  NGOs,  universities,  and 
research institutes.  
 
9.  The draft DNC seminar schedule for a given year should be in place by December of the 
preceding year. Each seminar will last 2 days; under the RETA, up to 20 seminars will be 
conducted.  To ensure that TA resources are used efficiently, in some cases a single regional 
seminar will be held to address the requirements of two or three DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
10  The cost of the RETA is estimated at $400,000. The detailed cost estimates are shown 
in Appendix 3. The RETA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11  The TA will be implemented over a 2-year period from late 2006 to December 2008. 
ADB will be the Executing Agency and COSO will implement the RETA. The resource persons 
for the seminars will be COSO staff with strong knowledge of DMC consulting industries and 
ADB’s policies and procedures on the use of consultants. All goods financed out of the RETA 
will be procured in accordance with ADB’s procurement guidelines. 
 
12.  Most events will be sponsored by national DMC consulting associations working in 
consultation with the government. The sponsor will be responsible for in-country organization, 
including advertisement, arranging and covering the cost of the venue, audiovisual equipment, 
providing secretarial assistance, making logistical arrangements, food and snacks during the

4   
workshop,  and  issuing  invitations  to  interested  participants.  The  sponsor  may  charge 
participants a nominal fee to cover costs; the participants will be responsible for their own travel 
and accommodation costs; an exception to this might apply to regional seminars. 
 
13.  The seminars will be conducted in English; however, interpreters will be used when 
necessary.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis for 
Developing National Consultants in Developing Member Countries, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
